Our military didn‚Äôt fail Afghanistan. The American people didn‚Äôt fail Afghanistan. Hubris of us the elites in Washington DC did. We failed to understand Afghanistan and we failed to understand the American public‚Äôs will for a long engagement..again.

What can we do now? Evacuate every person we can that helped us in Afghanistan. Skip the bureaucratic bullshit, get people on planes. Land them any where in the United States. We are a country of 330 million people. We can easily absorb 100,000 people.
If a war is not felt across all spectrums of society then you cant expect all spectrums of society to care.
In the end only a small sliver of US society had skin in the game for the success of Afghanistan. Asking for more to make it succeed (if at all possible) would have upended the unholy alliance.

But Afghanistan was always going to collapse. Keeping Afghanistan low profile stopped many including Congress from seeing institutionally how weak it was and asking for hard reforms or a quicker exit.

It was an unholy alliance that Washington DC and the Pentagon had gotten used to. Keeping casualties low, meant we can keep the war going and not admit defeat. You didn‚Äôt have to be the last general to ‚Äúlose Afghanistan‚Äù.  Or the President that pulled out.

Violence only produces trauma, trauma that can turn into anger, vengefulness and a continuing cycle of violence. That must be a lesson as we deal with conflicts around the world.
War and conflict never produce peace and stability. Violence and militarism, even when cloaked in the language of humanitarianism, are fundamentally at odds with human flourishing and opportunity.
I agree with President Biden: an endless American military occupation of Afghanistan was unacceptable.

Of course, the tragedy did not begin in the last couple of weeks. The hard truth about America‚Äôs longest war is that for 20 years, we made promises we couldn‚Äôt keep. The simple fact is that prolonging a war indefinitely would not have delivered a stable, peaceful Afghanistan.
